FacilityName: Columbia Fruit Packers, Inc - Airport Facility

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RMP PROGRAM

                                                                        EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 

                                                                        Columbia Fruit Packers, Inc - Airport Facility





The reason for this voluntary resubmission is due to several recent changes in ownership and employees.  In August 2014 Columbia Fruit Packers, Inc purchased 100% of the facility from then co-owner McDougall & Sons.  The facility name was changed to Columbia Fruit Packers, Inc - Airport Facility.  



Columbia Fruit Packers, Inc - Airport Facility is a fruit packing and cold storage facility, located at 201 S Union, East Wenatchee, WA.  The facility is located in Douglas County.



The regulated substance used at the facility is anhydrous ammonia (CAS#7664-41-7).  The threshold quantity established in 40 CFR 68.130 by EPA is 10,000 lbs.  Columbia Fruit Packers, Inc - Airport Facility has 17,500 lbs of ammonia in their refrigeration system.  The chemical properties of ammonia make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling ammonia in order to:

* Prevent unnecessary human exposure

* Reduce the threat to our personnel

* Reduce the threat to the community



Columbia Fruit Packers, Inc - Airport Facility uses other hazardous substances on-site, however they do not meet or exceed the threshold limits established in 40 CFR 68.130.  Policies, procedures and training have been prepared and implemented to reduce the risk of an accidental hazardous substance release for the safety of its employees and surrounding areas.



The accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:

* High level of training of personnel

* Preventative maintenance program

* Written safety procedures and safety equipment

* Use of accurate and effective written operating procedures



Columbia Fruit Packers, Inc - Airport Facility also complies with:

* OSHA and Washington State Process Safety Management rule

* Applicable Washington State safety regulations (WAC Codes 296-24 and 296-62)

* IIAR (International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration) standards for good work practices

* Applicable local fire code for handling of hazardous materials



The ammonia refrigeration system was installed to applicable codes and good practices at the time of installation.  Piping is elevated to prevent accidental damage to the system from moving vehicles.  Engine room doors are tight fitting and open outwards.  Other safety devices utilized include:

* Computerized controls, which can be operated remotely

* Suction trap hi-level float

* High discharge pressure shut down

* Low suction pressure shut down

* High discharge temperature shut down

* Oil pressure failure shut down

* High amperes shut down

* Automatic timer to prevent short cycling

* Oil filters plugged shut down

* 250 psi relief valves on high pressure side, to prevent overpressure situations

* 150 psi relief valves on low pressurew side, to prevent overpressure situations

* Emergency ventilation



Operating Procedures have been prepared by Columbia Fruit Packers, Inc - Airport Facility to be used by employees performing operational functions.  The operating procedures are kept in the refrigeration manager's office.  These procedures include: 

* Pre-start up procedures

* Routine operations

* Maintenance

* Response to minor releases

* Emergency action plan



Columbia Fruit Packers, Inc - Airport Facility has had no accidents involving ammonia in the last five years.



In addition to the operating procedures, management has established Emergency Response Guidelines for releases involving ammonia.  These procedures are part of the ongoing training. 



Management has decided their employees will not respond to large releases of ammonia.  Refrigeration personnel have not been trained, and do not have the appropriate equipment to enter into high concent

rations of ammonia.  In the event of a release, refrigeration personnel will attempt to shut down and/or isolate the area where the leak is located, if it is safe to do so.  They will immediately evacuate and report to the assembly area.  If, while exiting the building, they come across a person down, they will carry the injured person out of the building to the assembly area.  When 911 personnel arrive, they will take command of the incident and Fire Department HAZMAT Team will determine what action should be taken.  They will determine when facility employees may return to the facility.



The off-site consequence analysis was done using EPA's ALOHA, and population calculated by MARPLOT.  The numbers were updated on this resubmission based on current data.   



Safety improvements, maintenance of equipment, training of personnel and low employee turn-over are ongoing practices of Columbia Fruit Packers, Inc - Airport Facility.
